Posts.Content: Thank you toxophilite. I was a little nervous about what this diagnosis meant but when the consultant explained it - simply and with a boob drawing - it became clearer. Both he and my bcn said the choice for the op will ultimately be mine but I've got around 6 months to decide what is best for me. It's fantastic that you're still NED and that you got what you wanted.
Posts.Title: ER/PR negative & HER2 positive diagnosis

Posts.Content: Just had these results today so a little bit stunned but staying positive (or trying to at least). Also told today that, although the neo-adjuvant chemo is still the first step for me, the lymph node biopsy showed cancerous cells so I have a bone scan and CT scan scheduled for tomorrow to let them - and me - know if the cancer has gone walkabouts. Preparing for the worst but hoping for the best. On the plus side, my request for the PICC line has been approved because of my needle phobia, so that's one less thing to stress about. It looks like breast-conserving surgery is likely, providing the BRCA results don't put a spanner in the works. Lymph nodes removal seems to be a given. So, all in all, my glass is still half full!
Posts.Title: ER/PR negative & HER2 positive diagnosis

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone. Not_half I'm still waiting for another genealogy test result to come back as it was done at a different hospital and had a 2 month wait. The BRCA tests were rushed through requested by my onco and surgeon as they knew how worried I was. Aliowl fingers crossed that your results also show you are clear x
Posts.Title: A bit of good news

Posts.Content: Hi all, It makes a change to receive some good news so I hope you don't mind if I share it with you. I've just received a call to say that I'm clear of the BRCA genes, which is a huuuuuge relief as it was my biggest worry. Also the chances of recurrence is less than 50% which is better than I expected. I'm so happy I could cry!
Posts.Title: A bit of good news

Posts.Content: These gave me the giggles on the train and I got some strange looks so please keep them coming   A guy from my local council said "oh, if you haven't started treatment yet you're not really sick are ya" when I called them after my diagnosis. He hung up before I could say anything, although I was pretty gobsmacked and didn't have a response at hand!
Posts.Title: "At Least"

Posts.Content: I have the best of both worlds ronstar as I live in a village just outside North London so I guess I could walk in any direction and find something interesting to photograph. But if you were to cut me in half, I'd have I LOVE LONDON in the centre! I'll help you even it up a little ... unfortunately all my photos seem to be too big a file to post
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I haven't started my treatment yet (EC-T starts Friday 13th) but I love walking around London - the day before I found the initial lump I walked for 7 1/2 hrs - so I hope to continue doing that (perhaps not for as long). Tomorrow I'll be doing a trial run to Chase Farm Hospital, which is approx 2hrs away from where I live (by public transport) so obviously I won't be walking to whole way! Maybe I'll find something interesting to photograph while I wander around. Violetsniff feel free to angramise (is that  a real word?) My username if you want - sorry it's so long.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Dreamthief (/ stalker haha), There is an extra bus that goes into the hospital grounds but it was such a lovely evening (and I needed the exercise) that I chose to get off at an earlier stop and take a slightly longer route. The journey itself shouldn't take longer than an hour and 15 minutes each way (not including the train as I can stay at my friend's house if I get too tired) so it's not as bad as I thought. You're right though. I don't know how badly the fatigue will hit me, no matter how prepared I think I am.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Trial run to chemo unit hospital this evening (about an hour of walking in total, the rest by bus & train) and found this a couple of minutes walk away: Who wants to come with me? I don't drink alcohol but a nice refreshingly J2O sounds good right now!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: kathleen37 a very warm welcome from me. This is a fantastically supportive forum filled with an exhaustive wealth of experience and information. I can see that the lovely ladies have already given a lot of very good advice. I love your positive attitude, especially after the year you've had, and I pray that you get some great news. You are definitely in the right place here, I'm a newbie having just started neoadjuvant chemo for tnbc and everyone has been wonderful and very supportive and I know that they have made my journey easier. Good luck with your results Kathleen x
Posts.Title: Hello!!!

Posts.Content: I agree 100% with the anti brave the shave campaign comments. Before I was diagnosed with tnbc in June I would donate my hair to the Princess Trust every time I got it cut - from very long (to my bottom) to short every few years - and the last time was just after my diagnosis (very short bob) when I was told chemo was the first step of my treatment (which I started on July 13th). Now my hair is falling out at quite an alarming rate - about half has gone now but it was really thick and I had a lot of it so people haven't noticed yet - and still I can't bring myself to "brave the shave". I'm not sure if I'll be strong enough to do it when it's more obvious and I admire those who are. We who are going through this terrible disease are the ones who are brave as we have no choice but to be! I'm sorry if that offends anyone but it's how I feel. Evie S makes a truly valid point about the blind charities and I'm dumbfounded that Macmillan are being so insensitive to how strongly we feel about this.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I got my appointment letters today and I'm a little confused. I was told on Wednesday that I'll be having EC-T and I was given the booklets on Docetaxel. But the pre-treatment consultation letter includes literature of Paclitaxel. I will ask on Tuesday consultation but I was just wondering if they are both types of T and if anyone else has had their chemo drug changed before their 1st treatment? Also, how long roughly is the pre-treatment consultation? I'm having my PICC line put in on the same day but at a different hospital and didn't want to be late for it.
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Dreamthief Haha, thank you for the giggle, it is much needed today I've always wanted my own non-creepy stalker. I am definitely going to be discussing this at the meeting as weekly dosages will mean more adjustments - work cover, finances (damn zero hour contracts!), travel costs, getting 15yo son's a in g etc. I'm no expert on tea (apart from Redbush) but I'm pretty sure there's more than 2 haha. Talking of tea (sort of) ... has anyone tried Tetley's super squashes and are they any good?
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Thank you Dreamthief
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi Dizzy17 I hope the queasiness & fuzziness goes for you soon. I had my 1st EC today and it felt like my brain was doing a little Mexican wave & had a fuzzing feeling in my nose but it passed by the time I got the meds to take home. Fingers crossed that you cruise nicely on to the next one x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi fellow chemoers, just thought I'd better check in. Day 6 of 1st EC, meds all finished and seemed to have done their jobs. 3rd injection due shortly, still a little scary but has to be done. SE very minimal, thankfully, lack of sleep/restlessness and non-existent taste buds seem to be the only 2 but are also very hard to fix. Nothing tastes bad, everything just tastes the same, bland and tasteless, no matter how much flavouring I add. Oh well, it could be so much worse so I'm counting my blessings at the moment. I hope everyone is doing as well as they can be x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Tibu315 that's fantastic! It's so good to hear the Taxol is being kind to you and that you're closer to the end of your chemo treatment. Big hugs x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Betty Mango Thank you Betty. I'm sorry that yours has been postponed and that you're going through some discomfort. I hope it gets sorted out soon xx
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: That's okay Leolady56 I hope it went well x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: I've just had a proper look at my copy of the patient consent for and it says I'm to have 3 x EC and 5 x T neoadjuvant) and that I'll have to have antibiotics injections daily - not ideal for someone with a major needle phobia! - but it's only for the middle week of the cycle and it is for the greater good so I guess I'll just have to compartmentalise that. I do remember my onco telling me this yesterday but it's only just really sunk in. Seems like I misunderstood the consultant and it's HER2 neg - not positive as I thought he said - along with ER neg / PR neg (that I did understand as he explained this at great length). I know this means that certain options are now off the table but that's where my knowledge of this ends. Can anyone who had this diagnosis please shed some light on it?
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Happy belated birthday Gilly13. Sorry I missed your post (still playing catch-up), I had my first EC on Tuesday and, although I'm doing really well, my brain feels a little detached. PICC line bled on Saturday - probably because I'd been trying to do normal stuff and overdid it a bit - so went to A&E to get dressing changed and ended up there for 7 1/2 hours after ECG & blood tests showed abnormalities. Luckily I wasn't showing any other symptoms so I didn't have to stay in overnight. Needless to say, I have slowed right down! Gotta do my 1st injection tonight, little scared that my needle phobia may hinder but it has to be done so I will get it done. I hope everyone's doing as well as they can x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Thank you Sammystaff I will definitely ask about that on Tuesday. I don't have small children (mine are 27 & 15) but maybe it's because I work on Reception in a business centre surrounded by clients who tend to share more than a quick hello when they're ill (most of them don't know about my diagnosis) although I seemed to have been immune (or just very lucky) so far as I've never had a sick day ... yet. I hope your treatment is going well.
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Good evening. I hope everyone's treatment is going well. My PICC line went in on Tuesday, my muscles feel a little achy but no pain. My boss's daughter, who's a beautician, treated me to a mani/pedi today which made me feel as pampered as I felt when I had my hair cut into a very short bob (another treat this time from my closest friends from work). Upped my daily water intake to 3 litres, which was harder than I thought it would be, and made up a little chemo kit (using tips from this forum so thank you). So I think that I'm ready to face my 1st chemo session on Friday. (I'm having EC x 3 & T x 5 unless there's another change of plans) Please feel free to suggest anything else that I (and others) may benefit from.
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Busy day tomorrow with a lot of traveling - school run, feed friend's cats, pre-assessment meeting at Chase Farm, lunch (if no delays), PICC line insertion at Barnet, work (if no delays), water friend's plants, home for dinner, back to feed cats and finally home to bed (sleep permitting). I'm exhausted just thinking about it!
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: earwig o Good luck for today. I hope that everything goes smoothly and the SE are minimal xx Weeblemum Thank you. I wouldn't be anywhere near prepared if it wasn't for the wonderful ladies here so a very big HUG to everyone and thank you all xx ali owl Cooling spray is a very good idea, thank you. No doubt I'll be on here before then but just in case my brain goes awol - Good luck for next week, I hope it all goes well xx Good luck to anyone else who are having any treatment or procedures done. And hugs to all who need them xoxo I'd honestly be lost without this forum, it's a real godsend.

I know there are other posts with helpful tips and advice but I'm a little concerned that they may be missed by anyone who's new to this forum or anyone (like me) who are still getting used to navigating their way around.
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Sorry for the multiple posts, all I'm seeing is grey lines again so I'm having to log in and out to see & answer them (memory seems to have left me and I haven't even started chemo yet so can't blame chemo fog!) earwig o I'm glad that it was a positive experience for you today and I hope it continues xx maggiemee it's fine now thank you Maggie. I've realised that the pointy bit if the clamp was digging into my arm but with a little tweak all is good. Good luck to anyone who has treatment tomorrow, I'll see you on the other side xoxo
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi, 1st one done and I feel pretty good so far. I went into work this afternoon as normal (well I was a little late and I'm still here for another hour) but I am taking it easy and not whizzing around like Usain Bolt (my normal speed). I can't remember who else was having treatment today (I can blame chemo brain now, yay!) But I hope it all went well and that the SE are minimal for us all xx
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hello fellow chemoers, I hope you are all managing to stay cool. TheScriptFan I'm so sorry to hear that your 1st chemo is not treating you kindly. Unfortunately the first one can be a bit trial and error with the meds and SEs but the general rules seem to be: drink plenty of fluids, especially as it's soooo hot; eat little and often; try to rest when you can and listen to your body. Also, remember to tell your team about any SEs - I find keeping a diary helps - so they tailor the meds/treatment for you. I'm sure the other more experienced ladies will be able to give you more advice. Sammystaff I'm sorry about your sore throat. I've also been suffering from a sore throat for a couple of days so I know it's not fun. I've found that gargling salt water helps a little. I hope you feel better soon. Ms Jolly I hope your 2nd chemo goes/went well and that the SEs are minimal. I'm on day 13 of my 1st chemo and I've been very lucky. Only SEs so far are: headaches (days 6-10); taste buds have gone awol (since day 8); and 2 mouth ulcers (day 11-13). I've had more trouble with my PICC line than the chemo! It's bled twice (2nd time saw me in A&E for 7 1/2 hrs), the stitch came loose (reason for A&E visit) and today it has flared up with a lovely rash, which was revealed when they changed the dressings. They put a allergen-free one on but that has made it really itchy. Hopefully it's just heat rash but I'm going to take antihistamines to see if that helps. Sorry for the long post (waffling as per) and I hope you are all as well as can be x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi all, It looks like I'll be joining this month, probably within the next 2 weeks, and personally I can't wait - it feels like a long time coming. Everything crossed that it all goes smoothly and with minimal side effects for us all.
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: I'm sorry to read that some of you are having a tough time. I hope that it will soon pass and give huge hugs to those in need (and even to those who don't as hugs are free and unconditional) xoxo
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Pre-chemo appointment next Tuesday and first chemo session on Friday 13th! EC-T, have requested a PICC line and hopefully that will be done on Tuesday. So, see you next week!
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Ruby Rose so sorry that you've been having a hard time with chemo but it's good that your team have decided to stop it before it causes permanent damage. I'm sorry that you feel like your body has let you down, you've been through so much that maybe it's just simply trying to tell you it needs a bit of a break. Fingers (and everything else) crossed that your onco appointment goes well. Take care, be kind to yourself and enjoy your prosecco! Gentle hugs, Frankie xx Update: day 15 (1st EC) - throat still sore but luckily normal temperature. Also tummy being playing up a little today and rash still causing a little mischief but my SEs could've been so much worse so I'm just keeping track of them in my diary and taking each day as it comes. Take care and have a great weekend xx
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi Dreamthief Thank you for the information. Received a copy of the update letter sent to my gp today. It's definitely TNBC, also found out that it's grade 3 with node involvement. Neoadjuvant chemo was on the cards since 1st diagnosis on June 18th and I've requested a PICC line from then, which my onco agreed with mainly because of my needle phobia. Spoke to the chemo unit doctor today, who also agreed that this was best and he said we'll speak about in depth on Tuesday's meeting. I've been told I have this as my chemo will be at a different hospital so I'm comfortable there before my 1st session on Friday. Yes, you're right. I remember my onco mentioning G-CSF now. A lot was discussed on Wednesday so I think I got some things confused. Or I was still buzzing after being told it hadn't spread to my bones!
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi Betty Mango,  I'm so glad that your SEs have been minimal. I also had initial problems with my PICC line, even ending up in A&E for 7 1/2 hours due to stitch coming loose, but once that was sorted I got used to it being there and sometimes I even forget that it's there! I must point out that it was kinda my own doing as I was still doing everything I did prior to my diagnosis, needless to say I calmed right on down afterwards! Your adorable cuties have put a smile on my face. Take care & gentle hugs x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hopefully it'll be third time lucky and it won't get stopped for either because it's working. Good luck xx

Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: I was just cruising around and boy am I glad I found this thread. You are all talented, wonderful people after my own heart! I love to crochet and have many wips on the go at one time. Mainly because I start a project, then see another and simply have to have a go. Patience is not one of my strengths. I also dabble in knitting - usually when I have to as it hurts my hands - and cross-stitching. I have been known to do the odd loop rug kit. I'm not great but, as they say, God loves a trier! I love the knitted knockers idea and, unless there's a crochet version anywhere, I may have to see if I can knock a few up. As a technophobe, I have no idea how to post up any of my finished projects so I apologise for just being a viewer.

Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Remember, even in your darkest hour someone is always thinking of you.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Love that Aliowl
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I hope you all managing to stay cool. I have a worry about my 15yo son and I was wondering if anyone has/is going through a similar experience and has any advice. He's been through a tough time already as his nan, who he was really close to, died of cancer 18 months ago. She found a lump, had chemo & op but then it spread to her bones & organs and 9 1/2 years later sadly lost her battle. He had a few wobbles and tantrums, totally understandably, but all in all he coped very well. His school counsellor was fantastic but she's no longer at his school due to cutbacks. Now he's got to go through it all again with me. I have tnbc stage 3 with node involvement but, thankfully, it hasn't spread to my bones or organs. I start EC-T on Friday then I'll be having an op. I know it's not my fault but I feel guilty to put him through this again. And now he's older, and terribly hormonal, he's kicking off at school and he feels like all the teachers are against him. I'm getting phone calls almost daily and I have to explain that I've got health issues and that he's not handling it very well. I know his education is very important, although he really doesn't seem to care, and I don't know what to do. His dad tries to help but his wife rules their roost and limits his involvement. I'm able to deal with my battle but I can't seem to cope with the school situation and I'm really worried about my son. I'm not sure where else to turn.
Posts.Title: Teenage moods

Posts.Content: Thank you for the advice ladies. After the third call from his school in one day and having to explain my situation over and over I was having a major meltdown. I informed the school in great lengths what my son and I are going through and with them already knowing what he'd been through with his nan I just assumed they would be more understanding. My son and I have now had a proper talk about it and he has finally opened up to me a little, which is a start, and he's agreed to go to our gp to get him some counselling, which is a huge step for him.
Posts.Title: Teenage moods
